PaperTitle: Interactive Visual Exploration of Human Mobility Correlation Based on Smart Card Data

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Loads smart card transaction records from buses and subways, cleaning data by removing noise records, filling missing values, and extracting trip chains from raw records.
Outputs: Cleaned and structured trip chain records
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-A: Transaction records are collected from Aug. 1st to Aug. 31th in 2015 on buses and subways, where passengers swipe their smart cards to board and alight. Certain noise records are removed to improve data quality, including replicated records, records generated by infrequent passengers who travel less than 6 times in a month, records generated by transport staff, and records whose entry time equals exit time.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Clusters passengers into five mobility groups based on eight-dimensional mobility feature vectors using k-Means++.
Inputs: Cleaned and structured trip chain records
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-B: Characterized by the vectors, passengers are clustered into five mobility groups, namely, G1, G3, G5, G7, and G9, by using the k-Means++ algorithm.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Constructs a weighted mobility correlation graph where nodes represent passengers and edges represent correlation strengths based on mobility pattern and spatiotemporal similarities.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-C: The correlation network between pairwise passengers is pictured as a mobility correlation graph, i.e., G = (V , E), where V and E are the respective sets of vertices (discrete passengers) and edges (correlations between passengers).

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Labels true-positive trip companions by evaluating weighted similarities in the mobility correlation graph and applying a threshold for confirmation.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section V-D: Only those pairs whose weighted similarities are higher than a threshold, e.g., 0.8, are labeled as true-positive companions.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays spatial aggregation and trajectory distribution of passengers of interest on a 2D map.
Inputs: Filtered candidates based on temporal, spatial, or attributive query
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-A.2: Spatial aggregation and 2D trajectory distribution are visualized for candidates of interest in the map view b in Fig. 1, by activating the two buttons placed at the top right of the view.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays co-occurrence intensities of candidates on the 2D map using a color-coded heatmap.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-A.2: The first button embedded at the right-most part of Fig. 4 activates a heatmap differentiated by colors to render candidates' co-occurrence intensities in a global view.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays 2D trajectory distribution of candidates as routes overlaid on the map view.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-A.2: The second button triggers a frequency distribution of 2D trajectories differentiated by opacity in the same map view.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Visualizes segmented passenger mobility features using an edge-bundling parallel coordinates plot to highlight mobility groups and their correlations.
Outputs: Parallel coordinates plot showing group-based mobility feature distributions
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-B.1: Five mobility groups derived in Section V-B are visualized by colorful strips in a bundling PCP to portray group-based mobility correlations among passengers intuitively.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays mobility correlation graph using a node-link diagram where nodes are passengers and edges represent correlation strength.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-B.2: An instant overview of one correlation graph is shown in Fig. 6a, where multiple visual cues are adopted to present network-based correlations among candidates.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Visualizes reconstructed trajectories of passengers in a space-time cube, showing concurrent movements in space and time.
Outputs: 3D space-time cube showing trajectory movements over time
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-C.1: It is built in a space-time cube (STC) [5], with its base signifying a 2D geographical map, and its height rendering the time period ranged from 00:00 to 24:00.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays origin-destination flow between regions for passengers of interest, showing aggregated flows with width-encoded strips and color-coded nodes based on group classifications.
Outputs: Sankey diagram showing OD flows and spatial aggregation patterns
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-C.2: A Sankey-based OD flow [28] is rendered in the 2D map of the trajectory view in Fig. 7b, to reveal spatial aggregation patterns of passengers.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Allows users to set temporal queries with a three-level time widget and circular tool to specify traveling time ranges interactively.
Outputs: Filtered candidates based on temporal query
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-A.1: Temporal queries help screen passengers of interest whose traveling time is within specific temporal constraints. Fig. 2a presents a three-level time widget in the format of 'month date hour' from top to bottom.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Supports spatial queries by letting users draw AOIs or select administrative regions and stations on a map.
Outputs: Filtered candidates based on spatial query
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-A.1: Spatial queries are provided to delineate areas of interest (AOIs) in the map view b in Fig. 1, which can be zoomed and panned flexibly.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Allows users to specify ranges for mobility features such as diversity, regularity, and local outlier factors using interactive sliders on attributive bars.
Outputs: Filtered candidates based on attributive query
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-A.1: Attributive queries are designed to dig out passengers who present certain attributive distribution in their travel behaviors. As shown in the view c of Fig. 1, each bar corresponds to one mobility feature mentioned in Section V-B.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Enables interactive rotation of the 3D space-time cube view, supporting 360° rotation and navigation using mouse interactions and virtual compass for spatial orientation.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-C.1: Users can rotate the vertical axis in 360° to overview the view in any angle by holding the right mouse button. A virtual compass is placed on the top of the vertical axis with the red needle pointing at the North.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Allows zooming and panning in the map and node-link diagram views for exploring spatial data and passenger relationships.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section VI-A.1: Spatial queries are provided to delineate areas of interest (AOIs) in the map view b in Fig. 1, which can be zoomed and panned flexibly.
